title: Long-Distance Swirl Gravity from Chiral Swirling Knots with Central Holes
description:
This paper derives long-range gravitational attraction in Swirl–String Theory (SST) as a direct consequence of chiral swirling knots — topological filament structures such as the trefoil, cinquefoil, and stevedore knots. Each knot encloses a central rotational line that anchors circulation, leading to quantized loop integrals via Cauchy’s theorem. Using this quantization, we demonstrate how multiple quark knots merge into composite baryon tubes with additive circulation, predicting correct baryon mass scaling.

We show that two composite tubes sharing the same central line produce a deeper pressure well, providing a flat-space explanation for molecular attraction (e.g. in Hâ‚‚). The work embeds SST in an entropic-gravity framework, mapping swirl density to local information content, circulation to mass, and swirl clock slowdown to gravitational redshift. A Lagrangian and action formulation is presented, yielding Euler–Lagrange dynamics for the swirl fields.

Finally, we propose experimental tests: EMF-time impulse detection during vortex nucleation, spectroscopy of hydrogenic systems to probe local time dilation, and circulation quantization verification in composite tubes. This establishes a falsifiable, flat-space, topological mechanism for gravitational attraction without invoking spacetime curvature.

Keywords: Swirl–String Theory, Topological Gravity, Circulation Quantization, Composite Baryon Tubes, Entropic Gravity, Hydrogen Molecule Binding, Flat-Space Field Theory
